Report.notes: This is a default report generated by the OPEN-AIR software.

Broadband.Description: An amplifier designed to provide gain over a wide range of frequencies, from DC to several GHz, suitable for general-purpose signal boosting.
Broadband.Use: General-purpose test and measurement, preamplifiers for wideband antennas, and boosting signals for distributed antenna systems.

Low_Noise_LNA.Description: Specifically designed to amplify very weak signals while adding the minimum amount of noise possible, crucial for high-sensitivity receivers.
Low_Noise_LNA.Use: Radio astronomy, satellite communication ground stations, preamplifiers for spectrum analyzers, and deep space communication.

High_Power_HPAs.Description: Designed to provide significant power gain to a signal, often used as the final stage of a transmitter to increase transmission range or strength.
High_Power_HPAs.Use: Broadcast transmitters, radar systems, base stations for mobile networks, and satellite uplink communication.

Band_Specific.Description: Optimized to amplify signals within a narrow, specific frequency range, rejecting signals outside of that band.
Band_Specific.Use: Cellular signal boosters for a specific band, TV channel amplifiers, and filtering systems where only a particular frequency range is of interest.

Logarithmic.Description: An amplifier whose output voltage is proportional to the logarithm of the input voltage, used for compressing a wide range of signal strengths into a smaller, more manageable range.
Logarithmic.Use: Radar receivers, RF power detectors, and spectrum analyzers to display a wide range of signal levels (e.g., in dBm).

Omnidirectional_Dipole.Description: Radiates and receives signals equally well in all horizontal directions. Simple and widely used.
Omnidirectional_Dipole.Use: FM radio, Wi-Fi routers, short-range communication, general broadcasting.

Omnidirectional_Ground_Plane.Description: A vertical radiator with horizontal radials acting as a ground plane, providing omnidirectional coverage.
Omnidirectional_Ground_Plane.Use: VHF/UHF communication, amateur radio, base stations for mobile radio.

Directional_Yagi_Uda.Description: Consists of a driven element, a reflector, and one or more directors. Highly directional with good gain.
Directional_Yagi_Uda.Use: TV reception, amateur radio, point-to-point communication, long-distance communication.

Directional_Parabolic_Dish.Description: A large, curved reflector that focuses electromagnetic waves to or from a feed antenna at its focal point, providing very high gain and narrow beamwidth.
Directional_Parabolic_Dish.Use: Satellite communication, radar, radio astronomy, microwave links.

Loop_Antenna.Description: A closed-loop conductor. Can be small (resonant) or large (non-resonant), with varying directional properties depending on size and configuration.
Loop_Antenna.Use: AM radio reception, RFID, direction finding, amateur radio (especially for lower frequencies).

Patch_Antenna.Description: A flat, rectangular or circular metal patch mounted over a ground plane. Compact and low-profile.
Patch_Antenna.Use: GPS devices, mobile phones, satellite communication, Wi-Fi access points.

Horn_Antenna.Description: A flared metal waveguide, used for directing radio waves in a beam. High gain and good impedance matching.
Horn_Antenna.Use: Microwave communication, radar, satellite tracking, measurement systems.
